SAN:ServiceScopeDescription.SAN:Description:
• The sex offender’s initial intent to relocate, along with information about the offender (Relocation Package).
• The receiving jurisdiction’s acknowledgement of its receipt of the sending jurisdiction’s Relocation Package, together with a message describing the receiving jurisdiction’s registration requirements (Relocation Confirmation Notification).
• The sex offender’s compliance with the new jurisdiction’s registration requirements (Relocation Compliance Notification).
• The sex offender’s failure to contact the new jurisdiction (Did Not Report Notification).
• The sending jurisdiction’s resolution of a relocation notice (Relocation Cancelled Notification).
• The sending jurisdiction’s request for assistance from the USMS National Sex Offender Targeting Center (Relocation Package).
The following capabilities fall outside the scope of SIRS:
• Mechanisms for a sex offender to register with a SORNA jurisdiction.
• Disclosure of sex offenders’ information to the public.
• Exchanges of information between a SORNA jurisdiction’s registering agency and local law enforcement agencies.
• Creation of new criminal charges against a sex offender for failure to comply with registration requirements.
• Maintenance of data in criminal history repositories.

SANWSDL:ModelReference.SANWSDL:Name: Data::CorrectionsServices::CorrectionsComponents::CaseFileSubscriber

SAN:UmbrellaAgreement.SAN:AgreementDescriptionText: No umbrella agreements have been identified at this time.

SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:ServiceDescriptionSummaryText: Service for accessing information about a corrections subject with respect to release.

SAN:ServiceSecurityClassification.SAN:SecurityClassificationText:
Personally identifiable information (PII) about individuals must be readily shared between stakeholders participating within these exchanges. The service assumes that the stakeholders sharing information about the individual are authorized, and are authenticated before they execute these exchanges to meet their operational business needs.
The highest level of security classification for the information exchanged by this service is Sensitive But Unclassified (SBU). As a result, the service can be assigned a security classification of SBU.

SAN:RealWorldEffect.SAN:RealWorldEffectDescriptionText: Service for Treatment Information about the individual with community based providers so they are able to provide adequate treatment while the individual is released.
Service for Inquiries about an individual to obtain demographic, release and risk information.
Service for accessing information about a corrections subject with respect to release.
Service for Share Notifications about the individual with a broad array of stakeholders based as the individual proceeds through the corrections process.
Service for Medicaid Entitlements so that he individual has appropriate coverage, and help minimize costs for the correctional facilities.
Service for Housing Information so that the individual is housed appropriately based on their specific housing needs and risk profiles
Service for Treatment Status to be shared between the community based service providers and the supervisory authorities.
Service for Risk Assessment information so that the community based service providers better understand the risks associated with an individual.
Service to obtain Criminal History information.

SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:Sponsors: Office of Justice Programs, U.S. Department of Justice
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:DomainDescription: Law Enforcement, Public Safety, Prosecution, Corrections, Probation, Parole,USMS

SAN:ServiceCapabilities.SAN:CapabilityDescriptionText:
At different times and for different individuals, each corrections stakeholder may be a sending jurisdiction and a receiving jurisdiction—or, as expressed in GRA and SOA terms, each stakeholder can be a service provider and a service consumer. The capabilities associated with Corrections Information Sharing (CIS) are as follows:
• Inquiries about an individual to obtain demographic, release, and risk information. • Share Notifications about the individual with a broad array of stakeholders based on needs as the individual proceeds through the corrections process. • Treatment Information about the individual shared with community-based providers so they are able to provide adequate treatment when the individual is released. • Criminal History information. • Risk Assessment information so that the community-based service providers better understand the identified risks associated with an individual (risks to the individual and to the community). • Treatment status updates to be shared between the community-based service providers and the supervisory authorities. • Housing Information so that the individual is housed appropriately based on their specific housing needs and risk profiles. • Medicaid Entitlements so that an individual, if eligible, is able to enroll in Medicaid and other entitlement programs (e.g., VA programs) and receives all appropriate coverage.

SAN:ServicePurpose.SAN:Description: When a registered sex offender relocates from one SORNA jurisdiction to another SORNA jurisdiction, SIRS will enable the sharing of information that assists the jurisdictions with identifying, monitoring, and enforcing the offender’s registration requirements associated with the relocation process.

SAN:ModelReference.SAN:Name: Data::CorrectionsServices::Law enforcement and corrections community
SAN:ModelReference.SAN:Documentation: Law Enforcement, Public Safety, Prosecution, Corrections, Probation, Parole,USMS

SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:BusinessScenarios:
The services follow the simple request/response pattern. The subscription service sends an additional notification back to the requester. All requests are with respect to an Exchange Agreement between the provider and the consumer of the information. There are two types of agreements under consideration. There is a mechanism to incorporate the details of the exchange agreement (MOU) between the sharing partners from paper to the actual technical architecture. There is a proposed abstract model included in this document that can be implemented based on the actual environment (or ignored if the environment is not ready for this level of granular control). The other aspect of exchange agreements is more aligned with the actual owner of the information giving specific permissions to the producers and consumers of the information to be able to share. This is addressed separately under consent management.
Prerequisite: All subject interactions must include an ExchangeAgreementID URI which uniquely identifies the service exchange agreement under which the exchange is being made. The set of exchange agreements published by a service endpoint may be retrieved with the GetMetadata message. It is assumed that GetMetadata has been executed prior to subject related interactions between the parties. Some ExchangeAgreementURIs may be privately shared and not visible in the public GetMetadata.
The following scenarios were identified, and reviewed with the key stakeholders to validate the relevant data elements applicable for this service specification. This service specification does not include all scenarios, and is limited to the exchanges that were prioritized by the key stakeholders. The following section describes these exchange scenarios, and the associated data elements.
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:ServiceAssumptions:
• All messages exchanged will require a synchronous acknowledgement of receipt or return data.
• The acknowledgement of receipt will contain only metadata about the message. The metadata will consist of a timestamp and identifiers that uniquely identify the message.
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:ServiceDependencies: There are no outside service dependencies. • All interfaces depend on the information in GetMetadata. • The notification interface depends on the subscription interface.
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:ExecutionContext:
The service design will follow the GRA Execution Context Requirements. The GRA Execution Context Requirements guarantee that there is appropriate and necessary support for interaction between all services and that the adapters, connectors, and intermediaries have proper environments in which to reside. Network connections will need to exist between participating jurisdictions and the location of the intermediary host. Each endpoint location will need to provide a hardware environment for the containers.
Consumers are expected to retrieve and respect the metadata provided by the service deployments.
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:PoliciesContracts: Although no agreements have yet been developed for this service specification, it is assumed that these will be developed as part of the actual reference implementations.
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:Security:
The service implementation must follow the Service Interface Description Document (SIDD) to meet the Security Requirements.
• The service must adhere to the rules of the CJIS Security Policies regarding the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) level of encryption.
• Security Requirements: o Message Nonrepudiation o Message Integrity o Message Confidentiality
Note: The use of Virtual Private Networks (VPNs) or Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) for transport-level security in addition to these requirements is optional.
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:Privacy: Privacy requirements are currently under review regarding specific information model elements and/or groups of elements.
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:ActionModel: Action Model details are elaborated in Sections 2 and 3 of this document.
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:ProcessModel: Included in this section are the actions defined by CIS that are elaborated in the documents available in the artifacts/service model/behavior model. This is a DRAFT copy of the document, and will be replaced with a finalized version after the review cycle.
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:PhysicalModel:
This service interface will implement the following actions:
• SubjectQueryInterface
• SubjectSubscriptionInterface
• SubjectUpdateInterface
• MetadataInterface
• NotificationInterface
In addition to the above service actions, the responding partner system will implement an internal process to notify the requesting agency regarding the availability of event information.
The service will comply with the GRA Reliable Secure Web Services SIP (RS WS-SIP v 1.1). The service will implement the normative requirements stated in the GRA Execution Context Document.
The service will use WS-Addressing header information to implement the “publish subscribe” pattern required for implementing event notification.
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:ServiceInteroperabilityRequirements: The service will comply with the GRA Reliable Secure Web Services SIP (RS WS-SIP v1.1).
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:MessageDefinitionMechanisms: The service will comply with the message definition mechanisms identified in the GRA Web Services SIP.
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:AutomatedServicePolicies: No automated polices have been identified at this time.
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:AutomatedServiceContracts: No automated service contracts have been identified at this time.
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:NonAutomatedServicePoliciesAndContra: No nonautomated service contracts have been identified at this time.
SAN:ServiceDescription.SAN:ServiceTesting: Service Testing requirements will be identified between requesting agencies and specific partnering corrections organizations.
